newsitem.title: BELGIUM: SGB DENIES SELLING ACCOR SHARES.
newsitem.headline: SGB DENIES SELLING ACCOR SHARES.

text.p: Belgian holding company Societe Generale de Belgique SA (SGB) on Thursday denied market talk that it had sold some of its stake in French hotel group Accor.

"We have sold nothing. SGB has taken no decision about Accor," an SGB spokeswoman told Reuters. She declined further comment. Earlier on Thursday French fund managers said that SGB, a unit of French financial group Cie de Suez , was on the verge of selling its holdings in Accor, and that they themselves had been sounded out about their interest in buying Accor shares.
Asked whether SGB was considering selling its Accor stake, the SGB spokeswoman declined to comment.
SGB has a 9.23 percent stake in the French hotel group.
In October, Suez chief executive officer Gerald Mestrallet told a Belgian newspaper that Accor was not a strategic participation for Suez.

Some analysts consider it would make sense for SGB to sell the Accor stake. SGB has a tradition of trying to have controlling stakes in all its subsidiaries, and past efforts to have a bigger say and stake in Accor have been blocked by its independent-minded management. SGB also has a lot of debt.
SGB has 32 billion Belgian francs worth of debt, following its acquisition of an extra 25 percent stake in its Tractebel unit late last year.
SGB's 3,053,509 million Accor shares -- at the current 742 French francs per share and at a French franc worth 6.11 Belgian francs -- is worth about 13.8 billion Belgian francs.
